Posts.EditableText:
I'm talking about the "rich text box"... Richtext just means it has details about the font (size, colour, bold, underline, italic, font type) making it "rich".

The richtext box in Quest is the one where everything APPEARS - giving you all the feedback.

The box is supposed to be able to hold pictures (because if you drag-and-drop... Or copy and paste a picture) into the richtext box (I don't think it will work in Quest) then the picture actually DOES appear...

I remember that the way I looked at was talking about byte arrays and stuff like that - I just can't be bothered to go through all the loading, converting it into a bitmap, storing THAT, then putting it into the richtextbox one pixel at a time....
Posts.HTML:

Posts.EditableText:
Erm, I remember way back in the day's of playing text games on my Acorn Electron (erm, BBC Micro anyone....) where you typed in "fill bottle" and got "with what?" as a reply.... You could also type "picture" and got - guess what? A picture!!!

I'm guessing the picture only had like 16 different colours, but it was still a picture. Now there is nothing wrong with wanting a couple of pictures in text-based games, it allows the game creator to come closer to what they want to achieve. ASCII art is nice sometimes - but that requires that the player use a certain font (which they may not have) and a certain size - then if you want colour in there you need to add in all the codes for that too. Using normal .gif pictures are brillient and VERY small.

ASCII art is good for little maps (if you're using a game like that) but not really for getting a picture across... Plus what's the point in having an ascii picture instead of just the .gif picture? Less quality/detail and it's a picture non-the-less... Having ascii art pictures is just as bad as a normal picture file.

ASCII art is nice sometimes - but that requires that the player use a certain font (which they may not have) and a certain size - then if you want colour in there you need to add in all the codes for that too. ASCII art is good for little maps (if you're using a game like that) but not really for getting a picture across... Plus what's the point in having an ascii picture instead of just the .gif picture? Less quality/detail and it's a picture non-the-less... Having ascii art pictures is just as bad as a normal picture file.

Yeah - so ASCII can move now? I think not.

And you can't have colour ASCII - ASCII doesn't include any colour information.

Ok, see, that's not ascii art making it move, it's a script in the webpage going through a sequence of images made by taking screenshots and loading them into an ascii conversion program. So basically, some guy who can't make ascii art himself but had a little know-how with javascript or something, made something utterly retarded to impress uber-dorks such as yourself.

Looking at the source, it appears he just used some premade script.

Posts.EditableText: ASCII (American Standard Code for Information Interchange) is a list of 255 characters which include [b:112pa364]no colors, animation, etc.[/b:112pa364] If you took that animation, froze it, and stripped it of all colors, then it would be ASCII art. The letters themselves are ASCII, but that is it.
Posts.HTML: ASCII (American Standard Code for Information Interchange) is a list of 255 characters which include no colors, animation, etc. If you took that animation, froze it, and stripped it of all colors, then it would be ASCII art. The letters themselves are ASCII, but that is it.
